Reusable is better than redundant

Design systems with components, styles, and patterns can accelerate product development. A scalable design system helps remove inconsistencies and redundant work while creating space for more elevated design thinking (hello UX research).

These systems become a shared language between teams, helping with communication while visioning (what can we do?) and developing (what can we use?).

Design systems require maintenance and updates. They are a product serving products and benefit from feedback and research.

Discover

It all starts with an audit. Not only UI elements captured in design files, but the SCSS, the coded components, documentation, and instructional copy as well. This is also an opportunity to align the system to current accessibility standards.

An audit of your current UI, language, and code helps define design principles, direction, and strategy. It's not just about headers and buttons. This shared language includes language and tone, requirements, and process documentation.

Everything bespoke

An imagined (but rather common) conversation: a designer searching for a component that's been wireframed and spec'd countless times.

Seemingly, the easiest solution is to make a new one.

Creating new wireframes and specs adds to the design debt.

Redundant design work creates redundant development work. Not having a 'single source of truth' costs time and effort.

Designing with components

Now imagine a conversation where one designer points the other to a components design document.

No reduncancy or inconsistencies and no extra work!

Quick work with no added design debt and no dev time required.

When teams are moving this fast, there's room to elevate design thinking beyond pixel pushing and towards scalable solutions that impact the user experience across the product suite.

Develop

Once you understand what UI elements and components your products need and your platform supports, you can begin updating and/or building within the prescribed visual styles. Creating consistency with type, color, spacing, components, and patterns extends the shared language the team created along to the user.

Getting feedback on the design system comes from the internal teams, as well as users. The goal is to find the UI solution that scales, promotes consistency, and is accessible to all.

Maintain

A design system is an evolving product. As product needs, aesthetics, and accessibility guidelines change, the system needs to be able to adapt. If your products are using the system, and UX research is part of the development process, you'll always have access to valuable feedback on where updates are needed.

Just as design systems support research, by continuing to apply the discover, develop, and validate process to researching your system helps uncover any potential gaps that may exist.
